author: Sarah Broadway
title: NWS confirms at least 4 tornados touched down in North Alabama during Wednesday's storms | News | waaytv.com
text: The National Weather Service in Huntsville say at least four tornadoes touched down in North Alabama during Wednesday's severe weather outbreak. A tornado touched down in the Henagar area in Jackson County Wednesday night. The EF-2 tornado touched down between County Road 425 and 322 at 10:54 p.m. three miles southeast of Pisgah. The tornado had a path stretching 10.22 miles long and 880 yards wide. Wind speeds peaked at 135 mph. The tornado ended at 11:20 p.m. three miles northwest of Hammondville in DeKalb County. According to the NWS, seven people were injured during the tornado. Officials say the tornado caused widespread damage including overturning a camper, partially destroying a home, and moving a mobile home off its foundation. The NWS says an EF-1 tornado touched down in the Old Town area in Madison County Wednesday night. The tornado started three miles northeast of Huntsville near Walker Avenue at 9:28 p.m. and ended at 9:32 p.m. four miles east, northeast of Huntsville. Wind speeds reached 105 mph. The path was 2.38 miles long and 600 yards wide. The NWS says several large trees were uprooted in the tornado and that the debris signature continued southeast over Monte Sano. No injuries were reported. Another tornado touched down in the McMullen Cove area, according to the NWS. Officials say the EF-2 tornado touched down just north of Little Cove Road four miles west of Gurley. It started at 9:44 p.m. and had a path .87 miles long and 275 yards wide. Wind speeds reached 122 mph. The tornado ended at 9:48 p.m. three miles west of Gurley. Zero injuries were reported. Some of the damage included siding peeling off a garage and partially uplifted roofs on four homes on Kenhurst Lane SE. Another tornado touched down in the Brigadoon area in Limestone County. The NWS said that tornado was an EF-3. It started at 8:23 p.m. where it touched down on the Tennessee River just east of where the Elk River meets it and then moved inland toward the Brigadoon neighborhood. The tornado had a path 2.22 miles long and .13 miles wide with wind speeds reaching 136 mph. The tornado ended at 8:30 p.m. eight miles north of Hillsboro. The NWS says no injuries were reported. Storm damage included a home with exterior walls that collapsed and part of the roof gone. Homes nearby had substantial roof damage, trees were uprooted, and vehicles were damaged.
